chapters.chapter_title: CHAPTER XIII. IN WHICH PASSEPARTOUT RECEIVES A NEW PROOF THAT FORTUNE FAVORS THE BRAVE

events.title: Alliance Formed to Rescue Aouda
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg commits to the perilous mission of rescuing a Parsee woman, accepting the risks to his life, freedom, and journey.
Sir Francis Cromarty enthusiastically joins Fogg's cause.
Passepartout is charmed by his master's decision, perceiving Fogg's hidden depth and developing affection for him; he readily agrees to participate.
The loyalty of their Parsee guide becomes a concern, questioning if he might side with the Indians.
Sir Francis directly questions the guide about his allegiance.
The guide reveals he is also Parsee and pledges his full cooperation, asking them to command him.
Fogg expresses his satisfaction with the guide's commitment.
The guide emphasizes the extreme danger, warning of potential horrible tortures if they are captured.
Fogg confirms he has anticipated these risks and proposes they wait for nightfall before acting.

The guide concurs and provides details about the victim, Aouda: a beautiful, wealthy Parsee merchant's daughter with an English education, appearing European in manner. Orphaned, she was unwillingly married to an old rajah, escaped, was recaptured, and condemned to death by relatives interested in her demise.
Aouda's story solidifies the group's determination to proceed with their rescue plan.
They decide the guide will navigate the elephant toward the pagoda of Pillaji.
They arrive near the pagoda and halt in a concealed copse, close enough to hear the cries from the ceremony site.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The project was a bold one, full of difficulty, perhaps impracticable.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They halted, half an hour afterwards, in a copse, some five hundred feet from the pagoda, where they were well concealed; but they could hear the groans and cries of the fakirs distinctly.

events.text_segment:
The project was a bold one, full of difficulty, perhaps impracticable. Mr. Fogg was going to risk life, or at least liberty, and therefore the success of his tour. But he did not hesitate, and he found in Sir Francis Cromarty an enthusiastic ally.
As for Passepartout, he was ready for anything that might be proposed. His master’s idea charmed him; he perceived a heart, a soul, under that icy exterior. He began to love Phileas Fogg.
There remained the guide: what course would he adopt? Would he not take part with the Indians? In default of his assistance, it was necessary to be assured of his neutrality.
Sir Francis frankly put the question to him.
“Officers,” replied the guide, “I am a Parsee, and this woman is a Parsee. Command me as you will.”
“Excellent!” said Mr. Fogg.
“However,” resumed the guide, “it is certain, not only that we shall risk our lives, but horrible tortures, if we are taken.”
“That is foreseen,” replied Mr. Fogg. “I think we must wait till night before acting.”
“I think so,” said the guide.
The worthy Indian then gave some account of the victim, who, he said, was a celebrated beauty of the Parsee race, and the daughter of a wealthy Bombay merchant. She had received a thoroughly English education in that city, and, from her manners and intelligence, would be thought an European. Her name was Aouda. Left an orphan, she was married against her will to the old rajah of Bundelcund; and, knowing the fate that awaited her, she escaped, was retaken, and devoted by the rajah’s relatives, who had an interest in her death, to the sacrifice from which it seemed she could not escape.
The Parsee’s narrative only confirmed Mr. Fogg and his companions in their generous design. It was decided that the guide should direct the elephant towards the pagoda of Pillaji, which he accordingly approached as quickly as possible. They halted, half an hour afterwards, in a copse, some five hundred feet from the pagoda, where they were well concealed; but they could hear the groans and cries of the fakirs distinctly.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The project was a bold one, full of difficulty, perhaps impracticable. Phileas Fogg, with unwavering resolve, had committed himself to a perilous mission—to rescue a young Parsee woman from her captors. Sir Francis Cromarty, eager and enthusiastic, readily joined the cause, sharing in the daring venture. Passepartout, deeply touched by his master's decision, saw in Fogg a depth of character he had not previously appreciated and developed a growing affection for him; he was quick to agree to participate.

Their loyal guide, a Parsee himself, became a point of concern—would he remain faithful to their cause or side with the Indians? Sir Francis addressed him directly, seeking assurance. The guide, revealing his own Parsee identity, pledged his full cooperation, asking only to be commanded. Fogg expressed his satisfaction, and the guide warned of the extreme danger—horrible tortures awaited if they were captured.

Fogg, prepared for the worst, suggested they wait until nightfall before making their move. The guide provided details about their intended victim, Aouda—a beautiful, wealthy Parsee merchant's daughter, educated in England, with a European demeanor. Orphaned and forcibly married to an old rajah, she had escaped her captors only to be recaptured and condemned to death by her relatives, who wished her demise.

This tragic story strengthened their resolve, and they decided that the guide would navigate the elephant toward the pagoda of Pillaji. Approaching near the pagoda, they halted in a concealed copse, close enough to hear the distant cries from the site of the ceremony, their hearts set on the daring rescue that lay ahead.

events.title: Pagoda Reconnaissance and Initial Assessment
detailed_summary: The group deliberates on the best method to reach Aouda inside the pagoda.
The guide, knowledgeable about the pagoda, confirms Aouda's confinement within.
Two potential strategies are considered: entering through a door while the Indians are incapacitated by drugs, or creating an opening in the walls.
They determine the final approach must be decided on-site but agree the abduction must occur that night, before the dawn sacrifice makes rescue impossible.
Around six o'clock, as night descends, they proceed with a reconnaissance mission.
The fakirs' chanting subsides as the Indians begin using opium and hemp, offering a potential window for infiltration.
Guided by the Parsee, they stealthily advance through the woods.
They reach a small stream, observing by torchlight the funeral pyre prepared with the rajah's body, awaiting Aouda.
The pagoda structure is visible nearby through the darkening trees.
The guide urges them forward, moving with increased caution through the undergrowth.
They arrive at the edge of a torchlit clearing where numerous Indians lie motionless in a drunken stupor.
The pagoda is clearly visible, but armed guards are actively patrolling the entrances, disappointing the guide.
Concluding that forcing entry through the guarded doors is infeasible, the guide leads the party back.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They then discussed the means of getting at the victim.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty also saw that nothing could be attempted in that direction.

events.text_segment:
They then discussed the means of getting at the victim. The guide was familiar with the pagoda of Pillaji, in which, as he declared, the young woman was imprisoned. Could they enter any of its doors while the whole party of Indians was plunged in a drunken sleep, or was it safer to attempt to make a hole in the walls? This could only be determined at the moment and the place themselves; but it was certain that the abduction must be made that night, and not when, at break of day, the victim was led to her funeral pyre. Then no human intervention could save her.
As soon as night fell, about six o’clock, they decided to make a reconnaissance around the pagoda. The cries of the fakirs were just ceasing; the Indians were in the act of plunging themselves into the drunkenness caused by liquid opium mingled with hemp, and it might be possible to slip between them to the temple itself.
The Parsee, leading the others, noiselessly crept through the wood, and in ten minutes they found themselves on the banks of a small stream, whence, by the light of the rosin torches, they perceived a pyre of wood, on the top of which lay the embalmed body of the rajah, which was to be burned with his wife. The pagoda, whose minarets loomed above the trees in the deepening dusk, stood a hundred steps away.
“Come!” whispered the guide.
He slipped more cautiously than ever through the brush, followed by his companions; the silence around was only broken by the low murmuring of the wind among the branches.
Soon the Parsee stopped on the borders of the glade, which was lit up by the torches. The ground was covered by groups of the Indians, motionless in their drunken sleep; it seemed a battlefield strewn with the dead. Men, women, and children lay together.
In the background, among the trees, the pagoda of Pillaji loomed distinctly. Much to the guide’s disappointment, the guards of the rajah, lighted by torches, were watching at the doors and marching to and fro with naked sabres; probably the priests, too, were watching within.
The Parsee, now convinced that it was impossible to force an entrance to the temple, advanced no farther, but led his companions back again. Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis Cromarty also saw that nothing could be attempted in that direction.

It was agreed that the final decision would be made on the spot, but the abduction had to take place that very night, before the dawn sacrifice made rescue impossible.

As evening fell around six o'clock, they set out on a reconnaissance mission. The fakirs' chants gradually ceased as the Indians began to indulge in opium and hemp, creating a window of opportunity for infiltration. Concluding that forcing entry through the guarded doors was impossible, the guide led the party back, contemplating their next move.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
They then discussed the means of getting at the victim, considering various strategies that might be employed to reach him without arousing suspicion. Phileas Fogg, ever the meticulous planner, suggested they could use the underground tunnels beneath London, which were seldom used and known only to a few. Passepartout, his loyal servant, was quick to point out the dangers involved, but Fogg was resolute, believing that their success depended on careful timing and precise execution.

Meanwhile, Detective Fix, who had been quietly observing their conversation, grew increasingly suspicious. He wondered if their plans were as innocent as they appeared, or if they concealed a darker purpose. Fix's mind raced through the possibilities, contemplating whether they might be involved in some clandestine activity. He decided to keep a close watch on their movements, determined to uncover the truth.

As they prepared to move, Aouda, who had been listening intently, expressed her concern for the victim's safety. She urged them to consider more humane methods, emphasizing that violence or deception might only complicate matters further. Fogg nodded thoughtfully, acknowledging her point, and suggested that they might attempt to communicate with the victim directly, perhaps through a trusted intermediary.

The group then devised a plan to approach the victim discreetly, using a combination of the underground passages and their knowledge of the city’s lesser-known routes. Passepartout was tasked with procuring the necessary equipment and ensuring that their movements remained concealed from prying eyes. They agreed to meet at a designated point near the river, where they could coordinate their efforts without attracting attention.

As night fell, they set out under the cover of darkness, moving swiftly and silently through the labyrinthine tunnels beneath London. The city’s shadows cloaked their actions, and they felt a mixture of anticipation and apprehension. Every step brought them closer to their goal, and they knew that success depended on their ability to remain calm and focused.

Meanwhile, Detective Fix continued his surveillance, unaware that he was about to be outmaneuvered by the very individuals he was trying to catch. The game of cat and mouse was about to reach a new level, with each side playing their part in a complex dance of deception and pursuit.

events.title: Thwarted Attempt to Breach the Pagoda Wall
detailed_summary: The group halts and discusses their options in hushed tones.
Sir Francis notes it is only eight o'clock and speculates the guards might eventually fall asleep.
The guide concedes it's a possibility.
They find cover at the base of a tree and settle in to wait.
Time drags on; the guide periodically ventures out to check the guards' status.
The guards remain alert under the torchlight, and a faint light is visible from within the pagoda.
By midnight, hope diminishes as the guards show no signs of sleeping, making the wall-breaching plan necessary.
A remaining uncertainty is whether priests are guarding Aouda inside as vigilantly as the soldiers outside.
Following a final consultation, the guide signals readiness for the attempt.
They navigate a circuitous route to approach the pagoda from the rear.
They reach the back walls around half-past twelve, encountering no one; this area lacks guards, windows, or doors.
The darkness of the waning, cloud-covered moon and dense trees aids their concealment.
Acknowledging the need to create an opening, they rely on their pocket-knives.
The temple's brick and wood construction seems amenable to their tools.
The guide and Passepartout begin quietly working to remove bricks, aiming for a two-foot wide aperture.
Their progress is suddenly interrupted by a cry from inside, quickly answered by cries from outside.
Fearing detection and an alarm, they prudently withdraw into the woods, led by Fogg and Sir Francis.
They wait, prepared to resume, but guards unexpectedly appear and take positions at the rear of the temple, blocking their planned entry point.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They stopped, and engaged in a whispered colloquy.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It would be difficult to describe the disappointment of the party, thus interrupted in their work.

events.text_segment:
They stopped, and engaged in a whispered colloquy.
“It is only eight now,” said the brigadier, “and these guards may also go to sleep.”
“It is not impossible,” returned the Parsee.
They lay down at the foot of a tree, and waited.
The time seemed long; the guide ever and anon left them to take an observation on the edge of the wood, but the guards watched steadily by the glare of the torches, and a dim light crept through the windows of the pagoda.
They waited till midnight; but no change took place among the guards, and it became apparent that their yielding to sleep could not be counted on. The other plan must be carried out; an opening in the walls of the pagoda must be made. It remained to ascertain whether the priests were watching by the side of their victim as assiduously as were the soldiers at the door.
After a last consultation, the guide announced that he was ready for the attempt, and advanced, followed by the others. They took a roundabout way, so as to get at the pagoda on the rear. They reached the walls about half-past twelve, without having met anyone; here there was no guard, nor were there either windows or doors.
The night was dark. The moon, on the wane, scarcely left the horizon, and was covered with heavy clouds; the height of the trees deepened the darkness.
It was not enough to reach the walls; an opening in them must be accomplished, and to attain this purpose the party only had their pocket-knives. Happily the temple walls were built of brick and wood, which could be penetrated with little difficulty; after one brick had been taken out, the rest would yield easily.
They set noiselessly to work, and the Parsee on one side and Passepartout on the other began to loosen the bricks so as to make an aperture two feet wide. They were getting on rapidly, when suddenly a cry was heard in the interior of the temple, followed almost instantly by other cries replying from the outside. Passepartout and the guide stopped. Had they been heard? Was the alarm being given? Common prudence urged them to retire, and they did so, followed by Phileas Fogg and Sir Francis. They again hid themselves in the wood, and waited till the disturbance, whatever it might be, ceased, holding themselves ready to resume their attempt without delay. But, awkwardly enough, the guards now appeared at the rear of the temple, and there installed themselves, in readiness to prevent a surprise.
It would be difficult to describe the disappointment of the party, thus interrupted in their work.

events.title: Rescue Appears Lost; Fogg Remains Hopeful
detailed_summary: The group is deeply dismayed, as reaching Aouda now seems impossible.
Sir Francis clenches his fists in frustration, Passepartout is extremely agitated, and the guide gnashes his teeth in anger.
Phileas Fogg remains outwardly calm and unemotional.
Sir Francis whispers that they have no option but to depart.
The guide concurs with this assessment of hopelessness.
Fogg firmly tells them to wait, reminding them he has until the next morning to reach Allahabad.
Sir Francis questions Fogg's hope, pointing out that dawn is approaching.
Fogg enigmatically suggests that the lost chance might reappear at the very last moment.
Sir Francis studies Fogg, trying to understand his cool demeanor and plan – perhaps a reckless attempt to snatch Aouda during the sacrifice itself.
Though considering Fogg's potential plan foolhardy, Sir Francis agrees to stay until the end.
The guide leads them to a position at the rear of the glade to watch the sleeping assembly.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her?
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The guide led them to the rear of the glade, where they were able to observe the sleeping groups.

events.text_segment:
They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her? Sir Francis shook his fists, Passepartout was beside himself, and the guide gnashed his teeth with rage. The tranquil Fogg waited, without betraying any emotion.
“We have nothing to do but to go away,” whispered Sir Francis.
“Nothing but to go away,” echoed the guide.
“Stop,” said Fogg. “I am only due at Allahabad tomorrow before noon.”
“But what can you hope to do?” asked Sir Francis. “In a few hours it will be daylight, and—”
“The chance which now seems lost may present itself at the last moment.”
Sir Francis would have liked to read Phileas Fogg’s eyes. What was this cool Englishman thinking of? Was he planning to make a rush for the young woman at the very moment of the sacrifice, and boldly snatch her from her executioners?
This would be utter folly, and it was hard to admit that Fogg was such a fool. Sir Francis consented, however, to remain to the end of this terrible drama. The guide led them to the rear of the glade, where they were able to observe the sleeping groups.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
They could not now reach the victim; how, then, could they save her?

The group stood in despair, their hopes dashed by the insurmountable obstacle before them. Sir Francis Cromarty clenched his fists, frustration etched into his face, while Passepartout's agitation made him tremble, and the guide gnashed his teeth in anger. Phileas Fogg, however, remained outwardly calm, his expression unreadable.

"We have no choice but to depart," Sir Francis whispered, voice trembling.

The guide nodded in agreement, their collective hopelessness palpable.

Fogg, however, held up a hand, commanding patience. "Wait," he said quietly. "I have until dawn to reach Allahabad."

Sir Francis looked at him skeptically. "Dawn is approaching. Do you still hold hope?"

Fogg's lips curled into a faint, enigmatic smile. "Sometimes, the lost chance reappears at the very last moment."

Sir Francis studied him, trying to decipher his cool demeanor and plan—perhaps a reckless attempt to snatch Aouda during the sacrifice itself.

Though he considered Fogg's plan foolhardy, Sir Francis nodded, resolved to stay until the end.

The guide led them to a position at the rear of the glade, where they could watch the sleeping assembly, their hearts heavy with anticipation and dread.

detailed_summary: Meanwhile, Passepartout, hidden in a tree, refines a daring idea that initially seemed absurd but now feels like their only recourse.
He internally commits to his risky strategy, seeing it as a possible, singular chance among the incapacitated crowd.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Phileas Fogg and his companions, mingling in the rear ranks of the crowd, followed; and in two minutes they reached the banks of the stream, and stopped fifty paces from the pyre, upon which still lay the rajah’s corpse.

events.text_segment:
Meanwhile Passepartout, who had perched himself on the lower branches of a tree, was resolving an idea which had at first struck him like a flash, and which was now firmly lodged in his brain.
He had commenced by saying to himself, “What folly!” and then he repeated, “Why not, after all? It’s a chance,—perhaps the only one; and with such sots!” Thinking thus, he slipped, with the suppleness of a serpent, to the lowest branches, the ends of which bent almost to the ground.
The hours passed, and the lighter shades now announced the approach of day, though it was not yet light. This was the moment. The slumbering multitude became animated, the tambourines sounded, songs and cries arose; the hour of the sacrifice had come. The doors of the pagoda swung open, and a bright light escaped from its interior, in the midst of which Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis espied the victim. She seemed, having shaken off the stupor of intoxication, to be striving to escape from her executioner. Sir Francis’s heart throbbed; and, convulsively seizing Mr. Fogg’s hand, found in it an open knife. Just at this moment the crowd began to move. The young woman had again fallen into a stupor caused by the fumes of hemp, and passed among the fakirs, who escorted her with their wild, religious cries.
Phileas Fogg and his companions, mingling in the rear ranks of the crowd, followed; and in two minutes they reached the banks of the stream, and stopped fifty paces from the pyre, upon which still lay the rajah’s corpse.

events.title: Passepartout's Specter Act Saves Aouda
detailed_summary: From a short distance, the rescuers observe the unconscious Aouda being placed on the funeral pyre beside the rajah's body.
A torch is applied, and the oil-drenched wood immediately catches fire.
Sir Francis and the guide physically restrain Phileas Fogg, who appears poised for a desperate, sacrificial rush toward the burning pyre.
Fogg forcefully pushes them aside, just as the entire scene undergoes a sudden, dramatic transformation.
A collective cry of terror arises from the crowd.
The multitude throws themselves onto the ground, paralyzed by fear.
The supposedly dead rajah appears to rise miraculously, like a phantom, from the pyre.
He lifts his wife (Aouda) into his arms and descends, his figure made more ghostly by the swirling smoke.
The terrified fakirs, soldiers, and priests remain prostrate, not daring to look at the apparent supernatural event.
The spectral figure carries the lifeless Aouda with surprising ease.
Fogg and Sir Francis stand stunned but upright; the Parsee guide bows his head, and Passepartout's reaction is assumed to be similar shock.
The figure walks towards Fogg and Sir Francis and abruptly instructs them, "Let us be off!"
The rescuer is revealed to be Passepartout himself, who had secretly climbed onto the pyre amidst the smoke and darkness.
He successfully freed Aouda by impersonating the resurrected rajah with bold audacity, navigating through the terrified crowd.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was Passepartout who, playing his part with a happy audacity, had passed through the crowd amid the general terror.

events.text_segment:
In the semi-obscurity they saw the victim, quite senseless, stretched out beside her husband’s body. Then a torch was brought, and the wood, heavily soaked with oil, instantly took fire.
At this moment Sir Francis and the guide seized Phileas Fogg, who, in an instant of mad generosity, was about to rush upon the pyre. But he had quickly pushed them aside, when the whole scene suddenly changed. A cry of terror arose. The whole multitude prostrated themselves, terror-stricken, on the ground.
The old rajah was not dead, then, since he rose of a sudden, like a spectre, took up his wife in his arms, and descended from the pyre in the midst of the clouds of smoke, which only heightened his ghostly appearance.
Fakirs and soldiers and priests, seized with instant terror, lay there, with their faces on the ground, not daring to lift their eyes and behold such a prodigy.
The inanimate victim was borne along by the vigorous arms which supported her, and which she did not seem in the least to burden. Mr. Fogg and Sir Francis stood erect, the Parsee bowed his head, and Passepartout was, no doubt, scarcely less stupefied.
The resuscitated rajah approached Sir Francis and Mr. Fogg, and, in an abrupt tone, said, “Let us be off!”
It was Passepartout himself, who had slipped upon the pyre in the midst of the smoke and, profiting by the still overhanging darkness, had delivered the young woman from death! It was Passepartout who, playing his part with a happy audacity, had passed through the crowd amid the general terror.

events.title: Escape Under Fire
detailed_summary: Shortly after the rescue, the four companions vanish into the surrounding woods.
The elephant rapidly carries them away from the scene.
The sounds of shouting and pursuit, along with a bullet whizzing past Fogg's hat, confirm their deception has been uncovered.
The actual corpse of the rajah becomes visible on the pyre.
The priests, overcoming their fear, realize an abduction has occurred.
They lead soldiers into the forest in pursuit, firing a volley of shots at the escaping party.
However, the fugitives on the elephant quickly gain distance, soon moving beyond the effective range of the bullets and arrows.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

events.text_segment:
A moment after all four of the party had disappeared in the woods, and the elephant was bearing them away at a rapid pace. But the cries and noise, and a ball which whizzed through Phileas Fogg’s hat, apprised them that the trick had been discovered.
The old rajah’s body, indeed, now appeared upon the burning pyre; and the priests, recovered from their terror, perceived that an abduction had taken place. They hastened into the forest, followed by the soldiers, who fired a volley after the fugitives; but the latter rapidly increased the distance between them, and ere long found themselves beyond the reach of the bullets and arrows.

events.title: Post-Rescue Celebration and Reflection
detailed_summary: The successful rescue mission concludes, bringing relief.
Passepartout expresses great amusement over his role in the exploit.
Sir Francis congratulates Passepartout warmly.
Phileas Fogg offers rare praise, saying "Well done!"
Passepartout deflects the praise, crediting Fogg and calling his own contribution a mere "queer" idea.
He humorously reflects on his brief impersonation as the husband of a venerable rajah.
Aouda remains unconscious from the ordeal, resting in a howdah.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

events.text_segment: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. Sir Francis pressed the worthy fellow’s hand, and his master said, “Well done!” which, from him, was high commendation; to which Passepartout replied that all the credit of the affair belonged to Mr. Fogg. As for him, he had only been struck with a “queer” idea; and he laughed to think that for a few moments he, Passepartout, the ex-gymnast, ex-sergeant fireman, had been the spouse of a charming woman, a venerable, embalmed rajah! As for the young Indian woman, she had been unconscious throughout of what was passing, and now, wrapped up in a travelling-blanket, was reposing in one of the howdahs.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The rash exploit had been accomplished; and for an hour Passepartout laughed gaily at his success. He was in high spirits, full of amusement at the part he had played in the adventure. Sir Francis Cromarty approached him with a hearty congratulation, and Phileas Fogg, with his usual calm demeanor, simply nodded and said, "Well done!" Passepartout, modest as ever, brushed off the praise, claiming that it was Fogg's quick thinking and daring that had saved the day, while his own contribution was merely a queer idea that happened to work. He chuckled at the thought of his brief impersonation as the husband of a venerable rajah, which had added a humorous twist to the ordeal. Meanwhile, Aouda lay unconscious in the howdah, exhausted from the harrowing experience, resting peacefully after the tumult.

events.title: Journey Continuation and Concerns for Aouda
detailed_summary: Guided skillfully by the Parsee, the elephant travels swiftly through the dark forest and across a plain.
They halt after about an hour's travel past the pagoda.
Aouda remains deeply unconscious; the guide administers brandy and water without effect.
Sir Francis, recognizing the symptoms of hemp intoxication, reassures the others about her current state.
However, he expresses grave concern for Aouda's future safety if she stays in India.
He warns Fogg that fanatics would find her anywhere in the country, even under English police protection.
Sir Francis concludes that leaving India permanently is her only path to safety.
Phileas Fogg states he will consider the situation.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain.

events.text_segment:
The elephant, thanks to the skilful guidance of the Parsee, was advancing rapidly through the still darksome forest, and, an hour after leaving the pagoda, had crossed a vast plain. They made a halt at seven o’clock, the young woman being still in a state of complete prostration. The guide made her drink a little brandy and water, but the drowsiness which stupefied her could not yet be shaken off. Sir Francis, who was familiar with the effects of the intoxication produced by the fumes of hemp, reassured his companions on her account. But he was more disturbed at the prospect of her future fate. He told Phileas Fogg that, should Aouda remain in India, she would inevitably fall again into the hands of her executioners. These fanatics were scattered throughout the county, and would, despite the English police, recover their victim at Madras, Bombay, or Calcutta. She would only be safe by quitting India for ever.
Phileas Fogg replied that he would reflect upon the matter.

As dawn approached, they reached the banks of a swift river, which they needed to cross to continue their journey. Fogg's calm demeanor remained unshaken, confident that their meticulous planning would see them through. The group prepared to ford the river, aware that every moment counted in their race against time to complete the circumnavigation.

detailed_summary: The group reaches the Allahabad railway station around ten o'clock.
The railway line continues from here, promising arrival in Calcutta within 24 hours.
This timing allows Fogg to catch the planned steamer to Hong Kong.
Aouda is settled in a waiting room.

events.text_segment:
The station at Allahabad was reached about ten o’clock, and, the interrupted line of railway being resumed, would enable them to reach Calcutta in less than twenty-four hours. Phileas Fogg would thus be able to arrive in time to take the steamer which left Calcutta the next day, October 25th, at noon, for Hong Kong.
The young woman was placed in one of the waiting-rooms of the station, whilst Passepartout was charged with purchasing for her various articles of toilet, a dress, shawl, and some furs; for which his master gave him unlimited credit. Passepartout started off forthwith, and found himself in the streets of Allahabad, that is, the City of God, one of the most venerated in India, being built at the junction of the two sacred rivers, Ganges and Jumna, the waters of which attract pilgrims from every part of the peninsula. The Ganges, according to the legends of the Ramayana, rises in heaven, whence, owing to Brahma’s agency, it descends to the earth.
Passepartout made it a point, as he made his purchases, to take a good look at the city. It was formerly defended by a noble fort, which has since become a state prison; its commerce has dwindled away, and Passepartout in vain looked about him for such a bazaar as he used to frequent in Regent Street. At last he came upon an elderly, crusty Jew, who sold second-hand articles, and from whom he purchased a dress of Scotch stuff, a large mantle, and a fine otter-skin pelisse, for which he did not hesitate to pay seventy-five pounds. He then returned triumphantly to the station.

detailed_summary: Aouda begins to recover from the effects of the drugs administered by the priests.
Her consciousness returns, and her eyes regain their gentle expression.
The narrative includes a poetic description of an Indian queen's beauty, implying Aouda possesses similar charms in a European sense.
She is noted to be a charming woman who speaks English purely, confirming the guide's assessment of her upbringing.
As the train prepares to depart, Fogg pays the guide the exact sum agreed upon.

events.text_segment:
The influence to which the priests of Pillaji had subjected Aouda began gradually to yield, and she became more herself, so that her fine eyes resumed all their soft Indian expression.
When the poet-king, Ucaf Uddaul, celebrates the charms of the queen of Ahmehnagara, he speaks thus:
“Her shining tresses, divided in two parts, encircle the harmonious contour of her white and delicate cheeks, brilliant in their glow and freshness. Her ebony brows have the form and charm of the bow of Kama, the god of love, and beneath her long silken lashes the purest reflections and a celestial light swim, as in the sacred lakes of Himalaya, in the black pupils of her great clear eyes. Her teeth, fine, equal, and white, glitter between her smiling lips like dewdrops in a passion-flower’s half-enveloped breast. Her delicately formed ears, her vermilion hands, her little feet, curved and tender as the lotus-bud, glitter with the brilliancy of the loveliest pearls of Ceylon, the most dazzling diamonds of Golconda. Her narrow and supple waist, which a hand may clasp around, sets forth the outline of her rounded figure and the beauty of her bosom, where youth in its flower displays the wealth of its treasures; and beneath the silken folds of her tunic she seems to have been modelled in pure silver by the godlike hand of Vicvarcarma, the immortal sculptor.”
It is enough to say, without applying this poetical rhapsody to Aouda, that she was a charming woman, in all the European acceptation of the phrase. She spoke English with great purity, and the guide had not exaggerated in saying that the young Parsee had been transformed by her bringing up.
The train was about to start from Allahabad, and Mr. Fogg proceeded to pay the guide the price agreed upon for his service, and not a farthing more; which astonished Passepartout, who remembered all that his master owed to the guide’s devotion. He had, indeed, risked his life in the adventure at Pillaji, and, if he should be caught afterwards by the Indians, he would with difficulty escape their vengeance. Kiouni, also, must be disposed of. What should be done with the elephant, which had been so dearly purchased? Phileas Fogg had already determined this question.
“Parsee,” said he to the guide, “you have been serviceable and devoted. I have paid for your service, but not for your devotion. Would you like to have this elephant? He is yours.”
The guide’s eyes glistened.
“Your honour is giving me a fortune!” cried he.
“Take him, guide,” returned Mr. Fogg, “and I shall still be your debtor.”
“Good!” exclaimed Passepartout. “Take him, friend. Kiouni is a brave and faithful beast.” And, going up to the elephant, he gave him several lumps of sugar, saying, “Here, Kiouni, here, here.”
The elephant grunted out his satisfaction, and, clasping Passepartout around the waist with his trunk, lifted him as high as his head. Passepartout, not in the least alarmed, caressed the animal, which replaced him gently on the ground.

Her beauty, which was of a rare and charming kind, was compared by the guide to that of an Indian queen, and her European features only heightened her allure. She was a charming woman, speaking English with perfect purity, which confirmed the guide's opinion of her education. As the train prepared to depart, Phileas Fogg paid the guide the exact sum agreed upon, surprising Passepartout, who thought Fogg owed him more for his devotion and the risks he had taken. Passepartout reflected on the danger the guide would face if caught by the Indians. The question arose of what to do with Kiouni, the expensive elephant. Fogg, recognizing the guide's devotion, decided to give Kiouni to him as a gift, acknowledging his service beyond the call of duty. The guide was overjoyed, understanding the immense value of the gift. Passepartout applauded the gesture and bid farewell to Kiouni, feeding him sugar lumps. The elephant, in turn, lifted Passepartout with its trunk in a friendly manner before gently setting him down.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Her recovery was slow but steady, and with each passing day, her spirit seemed to regain its former strength. The priests, observing her improved condition, became more hopeful about her eventual reintegration into her community. Aouda, however, was not content to remain passive in her fate; her mind was sharp and her will resilient. She began to secretly ponder her options, considering the possibility of escape or seeking help from outsiders. The temple's walls, once symbols of her confinement, now seemed to close in on her, yet they also fueled her desire for freedom.

One evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting a golden glow over the city, Aouda noticed a small opening in the temple's outer wall. It was a narrow crevice, perhaps a remnant of an old construction, that she had previously overlooked. Her heart pounded with a mixture of fear and hope. She knew that this could be her chance to slip away unnoticed. Carefully, she began to examine the opening, testing its size and the possibility of passage.

Meanwhile, the priests continued their rituals, unaware of her plans. Aouda's mind raced through her options. She remembered her companions—Phileas Fogg, Passepartout, and the others—who had come to her aid before. She wondered if they were still nearby, perhaps searching for her or planning her rescue. The thought gave her renewed courage.

As night fell, Aouda decided to make her move. She waited until the temple was quiet, then silently approached the opening. With great care, she squeezed through the crevice, feeling the rough stones against her skin. Once outside, she found herself in a narrow alley, dimly lit by a flickering lantern. She paused for a moment, listening for any sounds of pursuit.

Her heart pounding, she moved swiftly through the shadows, heading toward the river where she knew her friends had last been seen. The city was alive with the sounds of night—vendors calling, children laughing, distant drums beating. Aouda felt a mixture of fear and exhilaration. She was free, but the journey ahead was uncertain.

As she reached the riverbank, she saw a small boat tied to a post. Without hesitation, she untied it and pushed off into the water. The current carried her downstream, away from the temple and her captors. She looked back once, seeing the faint outline of the city, then turned her gaze forward, determined to find safety and reunite with those who cared for her.

Her escape marked a turning point in her story—a testament to her resilience and courage. Though her path was fraught with danger, Aouda's spirit remained unbroken. She knew that her future depended on her strength and the kindness of those she would meet along the way. With hope in her heart, she continued her journey into the unknown, seeking freedom and a new beginning.

events.title: Train Journey to Benares: Aouda Awakens
detailed_summary: Fogg, Sir Francis, Passepartout, and Aouda board the train for Benares, giving Aouda the best seat.
The eighty-mile journey is completed rapidly in two hours.
During the trip, Aouda fully regains her senses.
She expresses bewilderment at finding herself on a train, dressed in European clothes, among strangers.
Her companions offer her liquor to aid her recovery.
Sir Francis explains the events of her rescue, highlighting Fogg's bravery and Passepartout's clever idea.
Fogg remains characteristically silent.
Passepartout modestly dismisses his role as insignificant.

events.text_segment: Soon after, Phileas Fogg, Sir Francis Cromarty, and Passepartout, installed in a carriage with Aouda, who had the best seat, were whirling at full speed towards Benares. It was a run of eighty miles, and was accomplished in two hours. During the journey, the young woman fully recovered her senses. What was her astonishment to find herself in this carriage, on the railway, dressed in European habiliments, and with travellers who were quite strangers to her! Her companions first set about fully reviving her with a little liquor, and then Sir Francis narrated to her what had passed, dwelling upon the courage with which Phileas Fogg had not hesitated to risk his life to save her, and recounting the happy sequel of the venture, the result of Passepartout’s rash idea. Mr. Fogg said nothing; while Passepartout, abashed, kept repeating that “it wasn’t worth telling.”

events.text_segment:
Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Then, as her thoughts strayed back to the scene of the sacrifice, and recalled the dangers which still menaced her, she shuddered with terror.
Phileas Fogg understood what was passing in Aouda’s mind, and offered, in order to reassure her, to escort her to Hong Kong, where she might remain safely until the affair was hushed up—an offer which she eagerly and gratefully accepted. She had, it seems, a Parsee relation, who was one of the principal merchants of Hong Kong, which is wholly an English city, though on an island on the Chinese coast.
At half-past twelve the train stopped at Benares. The Brahmin legends assert that this city is built on the site of the ancient Casi, which, like Mahomet’s tomb, was once suspended between heaven and earth; though the Benares of to-day, which the Orientalists call the Athens of India, stands quite unpoetically on the solid earth, Passepartout caught glimpses of its brick houses and clay huts, giving an aspect of desolation to the place, as the train entered it.
Benares was Sir Francis Cromarty’s destination, the troops he was rejoining being encamped some miles northward of the city. He bade adieu to Phileas Fogg, wishing him all success, and expressing the hope that he would come that way again in a less original but more profitable fashion.

**CHAPTER XIV. IN WHICH PHILEAS FOGG DESCENDS THE WHOLE LENGTH OF THE BEAUTIFUL VALLEY OF THE GANGES WITHOUT EVER THINKING OF SEEING IT**

Aouda pathetically thanked her deliverers, rather with tears than words; her fine eyes interpreted her gratitude better than her lips. Her face was pale, and her voice trembled as she expressed her thanks. She recalled the suttee and the danger still threatening her, which caused her to shudder with terror. Phileas Fogg, perceiving her agitation, offered to escort her to Hong Kong, suggesting she could stay there safely until the pursuit died down. She accepted the offer eagerly and gratefully, mentioning she had a Parsee merchant relative in Hong Kong, one of the principal merchants there.

The train arrived at Benares at half-past twelve. Benares, called the "Athens of India," was built on the site of the ancient Casi, according to Brahmin legends, and was famed for its religious and legendary importance. Passepartout, looking out of the window, observed the city’s unpoetical appearance—brick houses and clay huts—an impression of desolation contrasted with its legendary grandeur. Benares was Sir Francis Cromarty’s stop; his troops were camped nearby. He bade farewell to Fogg, wishing him success and hoping for a future meeting under better circumstances. Fogg responded with a light handshake. Aouda expressed her warmest gratitude in her parting with Sir Francis. Passepartout received a hearty handshake from the general. The train then continued on its way.

---

events.title: Journey through Behar, Night Travel, and Arrival in Calcutta On Schedule
detailed_summary: Leaving Benares, the train travels along the Ganges valley.
The travelers observe the diverse landscape of Behar: green mountains, fields, jungles with alligators, villages, and forests.
They see elephants bathing and groups of Indians performing religious ablutions in the Ganges despite the cold.
The narrative notes these are Brahmins, hostile to Buddhism, worshipping Vishnu, Shiva, and Brahma.
A reflection occurs on how these deities might view modern, anglicised India with its steam technology impacting the sacred river.
The scenery passes quickly, sometimes obscured by steam.
Landmarks like the fort of Chupenie, Ghazipur, Lord Cornwallis's tomb, Buxar, Patna (opium market), and Monghir (industrial town) are glimpsed or noted.
Night falls, and the train speeds through the darkness amidst the sounds of tigers, bears, and wolves.
The sights of Bengal are hidden by night.
Calcutta is reached at seven in the morning.
Fogg has five hours until the noon departure of the Hong Kong steamer.
He checks his journal and confirms his arrival on October 25th, exactly as scheduled.
He is neither early nor late, having lost the two days previously gained during the journey across India.
The narrative suggests Fogg does not regret this loss of time.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

events.text_segment:
The railway, on leaving Benares, passed for a while along the valley of the Ganges. Through the windows of their carriage the travellers had glimpses of the diversified landscape of Behar, with its mountains clothed in verdure, its fields of barley, wheat, and corn, its jungles peopled with green alligators, its neat villages, and its still thickly-leaved forests. Elephants were bathing in the waters of the sacred river, and groups of Indians, despite the advanced season and chilly air, were performing solemnly their pious ablutions. These were fervent Brahmins, the bitterest foes of Buddhism, their deities being Vishnu, the solar god, Shiva, the divine impersonation of natural forces, and Brahma, the supreme ruler of priests and legislators. What would these divinities think of India, anglicised as it is to-day, with steamers whistling and scudding along the Ganges, frightening the gulls which float upon its surface, the turtles swarming along its banks, and the faithful dwelling upon its borders?
The panorama passed before their eyes like a flash, save when the steam concealed it fitfully from the view; the travellers could scarcely discern the fort of Chupenie, twenty miles south-westward from Benares, the ancient stronghold of the rajahs of Behar; or Ghazipur and its famous rose-water factories; or the tomb of Lord Cornwallis, rising on the left bank of the Ganges; the fortified town of Buxar, or Patna, a large manufacturing and trading-place, where is held the principal opium market of India; or Monghir, a more than European town, for it is as English as Manchester or Birmingham, with its iron foundries, edgetool factories, and high chimneys puffing clouds of black smoke heavenward.
Night came on; the train passed on at full speed, in the midst of the roaring of the tigers, bears, and wolves which fled before the locomotive; and the marvels of Bengal, Golconda ruined Gour, Murshedabad, the ancient capital, Burdwan, Hugly, and the French town of Chandernagor, where Passepartout would have been proud to see his country’s flag flying, were hidden from their view in the darkness.
Calcutta was reached at seven in the morning, and the packet left for Hong Kong at noon; so that Phileas Fogg had five hours before him.
According to his journal, he was due at Calcutta on the 25th of October, and that was the exact date of his actual arrival. He was therefore neither behind-hand nor ahead of time. The two days gained between London and Bombay had been lost, as has been seen, in the journey across India. But it is not to be supposed that Phileas Fogg regretted them.

events.title: Arrival in Calcutta and Immediate Arrest
detailed_summary: Phileas Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout arrive at the Calcutta train station.
Fogg intends to immediately board the Hong Kong steamer to ensure Aouda's safety.
A policeman approaches Fogg, confirms his identity and that Passepartout is his servant, and instructs them both to follow him.
Fogg displays no surprise, respecting the law, while Passepartout's attempt to question is silenced by the policeman and Fogg's signal.
Aouda is permitted to accompany them.
They are transported in a four-wheeled carriage (palkigahri) through contrasting parts of the city: the poor 'black town' and the affluent 'European town'.
No one speaks during the twenty-minute journey.
They arrive at a modest building, revealed to be a place of detention.
The policeman escorts them into a room with barred windows, informing them they will appear before Judge Obadiah soon.
The policeman leaves, locking the door behind him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He then retired, and closed the door.

events.text_segment:
The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. Phileas Fogg intended to proceed at once to the Hong Kong steamer, in order to get Aouda comfortably settled for the voyage. He was unwilling to leave her while they were still on dangerous ground.
Just as he was leaving the station a policeman came up to him, and said, “Mr. Phileas Fogg?”
“I am he.”
“Is this man your servant?” added the policeman, pointing to Passepartout.
“Yes.”
“Be so good, both of you, as to follow me.”
Mr. Fogg betrayed no surprise whatever. The policeman was a representative of the law, and law is sacred to an Englishman. Passepartout tried to reason about the matter, but the policeman tapped him with his stick, and Mr. Fogg made him a signal to obey.
“May this young lady go with us?” asked he.
“She may,” replied the policeman.
Mr. Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout were conducted to a palkigahri, a sort of four-wheeled carriage, drawn by two horses, in which they took their places and were driven away. No one spoke during the twenty minutes which elapsed before they reached their destination. They first passed through the “black town,” with its narrow streets, its miserable, dirty huts, and squalid population; then through the “European town,” which presented a relief in its bright brick mansions, shaded by coconut-trees and bristling with masts, where, although it was early morning, elegantly dressed horsemen and handsome equipages were passing back and forth.
The carriage stopped before a modest-looking house, which, however, did not have the appearance of a private mansion. The policeman having requested his prisoners—for so, truly, they might be called—to descend, conducted them into a room with barred windows, and said: “You will appear before Judge Obadiah at half-past eight.”
He then retired, and closed the door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The train entered the station, and Passepartout jumping out first, was followed by Mr. Fogg, who assisted his fair companion to descend. As they stepped onto the platform, the bustling activity of Calcutta surrounded them. Without delay, Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout made their way to the nearby police station, where a policeman approached them, confirming their identities and intentions. The policeman, after a brief examination, instructed them to follow him, and they obeyed without protest. Aouda was allowed to accompany them, and they were soon seated in a palkigahri, a four-wheeled carriage, which began its journey through the contrasting districts of the city—passing through the impoverished black town and the more prosperous European quarter. The silence inside the carriage was profound, each occupant lost in thought. After about twenty minutes, they arrived at a modest building, which was revealed to be a place of detention. The policeman led them into a room with barred windows, informing them that they would soon appear before Judge Obadiah. Without further words, the policeman left, locking the door behind him, leaving Fogg, Aouda, and Passepartout in quiet anticipation.

events.title: Reactions to Imprisonment and Fogg's Resolve
detailed_summary: Passepartout exclaims in dismay that they are prisoners.
Aouda, emotional but trying to hide it, tells Fogg he should abandon her, blaming herself for his predicament.
Fogg calmly dismisses her suggestion as impossible, stating he wouldn't be arrested for preventing a suttee and that there must be a mistake.
He reaffirms his commitment to escorting Aouda to Hong Kong.
Passepartout nervously points out the steamer departs at noon.
Fogg confidently assures him they will be on board by noon.
His certainty impresses Passepartout, who mutters agreement, though he remains deeply uneasy.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: But he was by no means reassured.

events.text_segment:
“Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair.
Aouda, with an emotion she tried to conceal, said to Mr. Fogg: “Sir, you must leave me to my fate! It is on my account that you receive this treatment, it is for having saved me!”
Phileas Fogg contented himself with saying that it was impossible. It was quite unlikely that he should be arrested for preventing a suttee. The complainants would not dare present themselves with such a charge. There was some mistake. Moreover, he would not, in any event, abandon Aouda, but would escort her to Hong Kong.
“But the steamer leaves at noon!” observed Passepartout, nervously.
“We shall be on board by noon,” replied his master, placidly.
It was said so positively that Passepartout could not help muttering to himself, “Parbleu that’s certain! Before noon we shall be on board.” But he was by no means reassured.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: “Why, we are prisoners!” exclaimed Passepartout, falling into a chair. Aouda, her eyes brimming with tears but trying to compose herself, looked at Fogg with a mixture of gratitude and despair. "You must leave me," she whispered, her voice trembling. "It is my fault that you are in this trouble. You should go on without me." Fogg, calm and unperturbed, shook his head. "Impossible," he replied. "I would not be arrested for preventing a suttee, and I am certain there has been some mistake. I shall escort you to Hong Kong as planned." Passepartout, nervously glancing at the clock, said, "The steamer departs at noon." Fogg looked at his watch and then at the sky, a confident smile on his face. "We will be on board by then," he assured them. Passepartout muttered something under his breath, still uneasy but reassured by Fogg’s certainty.

detailed_summary: At half-past eight, the policeman returns and leads them to an adjacent courtroom, already filled with Europeans and natives.

events.text_segment:
At half-past eight the door opened, the policeman appeared, and, requesting them to follow him, led the way to an adjoining hall. It was evidently a court-room, and a crowd of Europeans and natives already occupied the rear of the apartment.
Mr. Fogg and his two companions took their places on a bench opposite the desks of the magistrate and his clerk. Immediately after, Judge Obadiah, a fat, round man, followed by the clerk, entered. He proceeded to take down a wig which was hanging on a nail, and put it hurriedly on his head.
“The first case,” said he. Then, putting his hand to his head, he exclaimed, “Heh! This is not my wig!”
“No, your worship,” returned the clerk, “it is mine.”
“My dear Mr. Oysterpuff, how can a judge give a wise sentence in a clerk’s wig?”
The wigs were exchanged.
Passepartout was getting nervous, for the hands on the face of the big clock over the judge seemed to go around with terrible rapidity.
“The first case,” repeated Judge Obadiah.
“Phileas Fogg?” demanded Oysterpuff.
“I am here,” replied Mr. Fogg.
“Passepartout?”
“Present,” responded Passepartout.
“Good,” said the judge. “You have been looked for, prisoners, for two days on the trains from Bombay.”
“But of what are we accused?” asked Passepartout, impatiently.
“You are about to be informed.”
“I am an English subject, sir,” said Mr. Fogg, “and I have the right—”
“Have you been ill-treated?”
“Not at all.”
“Very well; let the complainants come in.”

"How can a judge deliver a wise sentence in a clerk's wig?" he said, removing the wrong wig and adjusting his own.

The judge then addressed the court: "How can a judge deliver a wise sentence in a clerk's wig?" and they exchanged headpieces again. Passepartout grew more anxious as he watched the big clock over the judge's seat, its hands pointing to a quarter past nine.

The judge called the first case, and Oysterpuff confirmed the presence of Phileas Fogg and Passepartout. "You have been sought for two days," the judge said, "on the trains from Liverpool, from London, and from Dover."

Impatient, Passepartout asked, "What are the charges?" Fogg, calmly, asserted his rights as an English subject. The judge then asked, "Have you been mistreated?" Fogg replied, "No, sir." The judge confirmed they had not been mistreated and ordered the complainants to be brought in.

---

This version preserves the original sequence, dialogue, and key details, including the judge's repeated announcement, the wig exchange, the clock, and the specific mention of the trains from different locations.

events.text_segment:
A door was swung open by order of the judge, and three Indian priests entered.
“That’s it,” muttered Passepartout; “these are the rogues who were going to burn our young lady.”
The priests took their places in front of the judge, and the clerk proceeded to read in a loud voice a complaint of sacrilege against Phileas Fogg and his servant, who were accused of having violated a place held consecrated by the Brahmin religion.
“You hear the charge?” asked the judge.
“Yes, sir,” replied Mr. Fogg, consulting his watch, “and I admit it.”
“You admit it?”
“I admit it, and I wish to hear these priests admit, in their turn, what they were going to do at the pagoda of Pillaji.”
The priests looked at each other; they did not seem to understand what was said.
“Yes,” cried Passepartout, warmly; “at the pagoda of Pillaji, where they were on the point of burning their victim.”
The judge stared with astonishment, and the priests were stupefied.
“What victim?” said Judge Obadiah. “Burn whom? In Bombay itself?”
“Bombay?” cried Passepartout.
“Certainly. We are not talking of the pagoda of Pillaji, but of the pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay.”
“And as a proof,” added the clerk, “here are the desecrator’s very shoes, which he left behind him.”
Whereupon he placed a pair of shoes on his desk.

events.text_segment:
“My shoes!” cried Passepartout, in his surprise permitting this imprudent exclamation to escape him.
The confusion of master and man, who had quite forgotten the affair at Bombay, for which they were now detained at Calcutta, may be imagined.
Fix the detective, had foreseen the advantage which Passepartout’s escapade gave him, and, delaying his departure for twelve hours, had consulted the priests of Malabar Hill. Knowing that the English authorities dealt very severely with this kind of misdemeanour, he promised them a goodly sum in damages, and sent them forward to Calcutta by the next train. Owing to the delay caused by the rescue of the young widow, Fix and the priests reached the Indian capital before Mr. Fogg and his servant, the magistrates having been already warned by a dispatch to arrest them should they arrive. Fix’s disappointment when he learned that Phileas Fogg had not made his appearance in Calcutta may be imagined. He made up his mind that the robber had stopped somewhere on the route and taken refuge in the southern provinces. For twenty-four hours Fix watched the station with feverish anxiety; at last he was rewarded by seeing Mr. Fogg and Passepartout arrive, accompanied by a young woman, whose presence he was wholly at a loss to explain. He hastened for a policeman; and this was how the party came to be arrested and brought before Judge Obadiah.

events.text_segment:
Had Passepartout been a little less preoccupied, he would have espied the detective ensconced in a corner of the court-room, watching the proceedings with an interest easily understood; for the warrant had failed to reach him at Calcutta, as it had done at Bombay and Suez.
Judge Obadiah had unfortunately caught Passepartout’s rash exclamation, which the poor fellow would have given the world to recall.
“The facts are admitted?” asked the judge.
“Admitted,” replied Mr. Fogg, coldly.
“Inasmuch,” resumed the judge, “as the English law protects equally and sternly the religions of the Indian people, and as the man Passepartout has admitted that he violated the sacred pagoda of Malabar Hill, at Bombay, on the 20th of October, I condemn the said Passepartout to imprisonment for fifteen days and a fine of three hundred pounds.”
“Three hundred pounds!” cried Passepartout, startled at the largeness of the sum.
“Silence!” shouted the constable.
“And inasmuch,” continued the judge, “as it is not proved that the act was not done by the connivance of the master with the servant, and as the master in any case must be held responsible for the acts of his paid servant, I condemn Phileas Fogg to a week’s imprisonment and a fine of one hundred and fifty pounds.”
Fix rubbed his hands softly with satisfaction; if Phileas Fogg could be detained in Calcutta a week, it would be more than time for the warrant to arrive. Passepartout was stupefied. This sentence ruined his master. A wager of twenty thousand pounds lost, because he, like a precious fool, had gone into that abominable pagoda!
Phileas Fogg, as self-composed as if the judgment did not in the least concern him, did not even lift his eyebrows while it was being pronounced. Just as the clerk was calling the next case, he rose, and said, “I offer bail.”
“You have that right,” returned the judge.
Fix’s blood ran cold, but he resumed his composure when he heard the judge announce that the bail required for each prisoner would be one thousand pounds.
“I will pay it at once,” said Mr. Fogg, taking a roll of bank-bills from the carpet-bag, which Passepartout had by him, and placing them on the clerk’s desk.
“This sum will be restored to you upon your release from prison,” said the judge. “Meanwhile, you are liberated on bail.”
“Come!” said Phileas Fogg to his servant.
“But let them at least give me back my shoes!” cried Passepartout angrily.
“Ah, these are pretty dear shoes!” he muttered, as they were handed to him. “More than a thousand pounds apiece; besides, they pinch my feet.”

The court-room was bustling with activity, lawyers arguing their cases, witnesses giving their testimonies, and the judge presiding with a stern demeanor. Amidst this chaos, the detective's gaze remained fixed on Fogg, who sat composed and unruffled, a picture of calm determination. Passepartout, noticing nothing, continued to watch the proceedings with a distracted air.

Meanwhile, the detective was gathering information, noting the movements of everyone in the room, especially Fogg. He was aware that the slightest mistake or oversight could jeopardize his mission. His eyes flicked to the clock, calculating the time remaining before Fogg's departure. He knew that the window of opportunity was closing.

If Passepartout had been less preoccupied, he might have realized the importance of the detective's presence and the threat it posed to their plans. Instead, he remained oblivious, his thoughts drifting to the upcoming journey and the adventures that awaited. The detective, meanwhile, prepared to make his move, confident that he was close to uncovering the truth and perhaps, preventing Fogg from completing his remarkable journey around the world.

events.title: Departure for the Steamer and Fix's Frustrated Pursuit
detailed_summary: Fogg offers his arm to Aouda and they depart, followed by a dejected Passepartout.
Fix still hopes Fogg might choose jail over forfeiting the £2,000 bail, and follows them.
Fogg's party takes a carriage to the quays.
The steamer 'Rangoon' is anchored half a mile offshore, signalling imminent departure.
It is eleven o'clock, giving Fogg an hour to spare.
Fix watches them board a boat heading towards the steamer.
He stamps his feet in frustration, exclaiming that Fogg is escaping after all.
Fix laments the sacrificed £2,000, calls Fogg prodigal like a thief, and vows to follow him to the ends of the earth.
He worries that at Fogg's spending rate, the stolen bank money will soon run out.
The narrator confirms Fix's conjecture is likely correct.
Fogg's expenses since London (travel, bribes, elephant purchase, bail, fines) already exceed £5,000.
The potential reward for the detectives recovering the stolen money is rapidly decreasing.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Mr. Fogg, offering his arm to Aouda, then departed, followed by the crestfallen Passepartout.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Since leaving London, what with travelling expenses, bribes, the purchase of the elephant, bails, and fines, Mr. Fogg had already spent more than five thousand pounds on the way, and the percentage of the sum recovered from the bank robber promised to the detectives, was rapidly diminishing.

events.text_segment:
Mr. Fogg, offering his arm to Aouda, then departed, followed by the crestfallen Passepartout. Fix still nourished hopes that the robber would not, after all, leave the two thousand pounds behind him, but would decide to serve out his week in jail, and issued forth on Mr. Fogg’s traces. That gentleman took a carriage, and the party were soon landed on one of the quays.
The “Rangoon” was moored half a mile off in the harbour, its signal of departure hoisted at the mast-head. Eleven o’clock was striking; Mr. Fogg was an hour in advance of time. Fix saw them leave the carriage and push off in a boat for the steamer, and stamped his feet with disappointment.
“The rascal is off, after all!” he exclaimed. “Two thousand pounds sacrificed! He’s as prodigal as a thief! I’ll follow him to the end of the world if necessary; but, at the rate he is going on, the stolen money will soon be exhausted.”
The detective was not far wrong in making this conjecture. Since leaving London, what with travelling expenses, bribes, the purchase of the elephant, bails, and fines, Mr. Fogg had already spent more than five thousand pounds on the way, and the percentage of the sum recovered from the bank robber promised to the detectives, was rapidly diminishing.

events.title: Journey Commencement and Fogg's Detached Care
detailed_summary: The journey commences on the 'Rangoon', a functional but less luxurious steamer than the 'Mongolia'.
Aouda settles in, though her accommodations are not as comfortable as Fogg might have preferred for the 10-12 day trip to Hong Kong.
Over the initial days, Aouda grows more familiar with Fogg, expressing profound gratitude for his rescue.
Fogg listens to her with characteristic impassivity, showing no outward emotion but ensuring her needs are met.
He visits her daily at set times, primarily to listen rather than converse, maintaining strict politeness but acting with machine-like precision.
Aouda finds Fogg perplexing, despite Passepartout having shared anecdotes about his master's eccentricities and the global wager.
Her gratitude shapes her perception, always viewing Fogg favorably due to him saving her life.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The “Rangoon”—one of the Peninsular and Oriental Company’s boats plying in the Chinese and Japanese seas—was a screw steamer, built of iron, weighing about seventeen hundred and seventy tons, and with engines of four hundred horse-power.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: After all, she owed Phileas Fogg her life, and she always regarded him through the exalting medium of her gratitude.

events.text_segment:
The “Rangoon”—one of the Peninsular and Oriental Company’s boats plying in the Chinese and Japanese seas—was a screw steamer, built of iron, weighing about seventeen hundred and seventy tons, and with engines of four hundred horse-power. She was as fast, but not as well fitted up, as the “Mongolia,” and Aouda was not as comfortably provided for on board of her as Phileas Fogg could have wished. However, the trip from Calcutta to Hong Kong only comprised some three thousand five hundred miles, occupying from ten to twelve days, and the young woman was not difficult to please.
During the first days of the journey Aouda became better acquainted with her protector, and constantly gave evidence of her deep gratitude for what he had done. The phlegmatic gentleman listened to her, apparently at least, with coldness, neither his voice nor his manner betraying the slightest emotion; but he seemed to be always on the watch that nothing should be wanting to Aouda’s comfort. He visited her regularly each day at certain hours, not so much to talk himself, as to sit and hear her talk. He treated her with the strictest politeness, but with the precision of an automaton, the movements of which had been arranged for this purpose. Aouda did not quite know what to make of him, though Passepartout had given her some hints of his master’s eccentricity, and made her smile by telling her of the wager which was sending him round the world. After all, she owed Phileas Fogg her life, and she always regarded him through the exalting medium of her gratitude.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The “Rangoon”—one of the Peninsular and Oriental Company’s boats plying in the Chinese and Japanese seas—was a screw steamer, built of iron, weighing about seventeen hundred and seventy tons, and with engines of four hundred horse-power. It was a vessel of moderate size, not as luxurious as some of the larger liners, but sufficiently comfortable for the journey ahead. Aouda settled herself into her cabin, which, though modest, was adequate, and she looked around with a mixture of curiosity and gratitude. Over the next few days, she grew more familiar with her surroundings and with her companions, especially Fogg, whose calm demeanor she found both reassuring and perplexing. She expressed her thanks to him for saving her life, and he listened with his usual impassive silence, ensuring her needs were met without outward emotion. Fogg visited her daily at the appointed times, primarily to listen rather than to converse, maintaining a strict politeness that bordered on mechanical. Passepartout, observing her interactions with Fogg, shared anecdotes about his master’s eccentricities and the global wager that had brought them all together. Despite her gratitude and the kindness shown to her, Aouda found Fogg somewhat inscrutable, yet she continued to view him with respect and appreciation for his actions.

events.title: Aouda's History and Fogg's Mathematical Assurance
detailed_summary: Aouda substantiates the Parsee guide's account of her history, confirming her lineage from a high-ranking Indian race.
She explains her connection to wealthy Parsee cotton merchants, specifically mentioning Sir Jametsee Jeejeebhoy, a baronet.
Her intention is revealed: to seek refuge with a relative, Jeejeeh (cousin of Sir Jametsee), in Hong Kong.
She expresses uncertainty about whether this relative will offer protection.
Mr. Fogg attempts to alleviate her worries, assuring her that arrangements will proceed with mathematical certainty.
Aouda gazes at him intently, but Fogg remains emotionally reserved and unresponsive to any deeper connection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Aouda confirmed the Parsee guide’s narrative of her touching history.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Aouda fastened her great eyes, “clear as the sacred lakes of the Himalaya,” upon him; but the intractable Fogg, as reserved as ever, did not seem at all inclined to throw himself into this lake.

events.text_segment: Aouda confirmed the Parsee guide’s narrative of her touching history. She did, indeed, belong to the highest of the native races of India. Many of the Parsee merchants have made great fortunes there by dealing in cotton; and one of them, Sir Jametsee Jeejeebhoy, was made a baronet by the English government. Aouda was a relative of this great man, and it was his cousin, Jeejeeh, whom she hoped to join at Hong Kong. Whether she would find a protector in him she could not tell; but Mr. Fogg essayed to calm her anxieties, and to assure her that everything would be mathematically—he used the very word—arranged. Aouda fastened her great eyes, “clear as the sacred lakes of the Himalaya,” upon him; but the intractable Fogg, as reserved as ever, did not seem at all inclined to throw himself into this lake.

events.title: Smooth Sailing and Andaman Islands Scenery
detailed_summary: The initial part of the voyage proceeds smoothly with good weather.
The ship sights Great Andaman Island, noting its prominent Saddle Peak.
The steamer travels close to the shore, but the local Papuan inhabitants, described as non-cannibalistic savages, are not seen.
The passengers observe the lush panorama of the islands: diverse forests of palms, bamboo, teak, mimosa, and ferns, backed by mountain ranges.
The abundance of swallows, whose nests are a delicacy in China, is noted along the coast.
After passing the Andaman Islands, the 'Rangoon' heads towards the Straits of Malacca, gateway to the China Seas.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The first few days of the voyage passed prosperously, amid favourable weather and propitious winds, and they soon came in sight of the great Andaman, the principal of the islands in the Bay of Bengal, with its picturesque Saddle Peak, two thousand four hundred feet high, looming above the waters.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The varied landscape afforded by the Andaman Islands was soon passed, however, and the “Rangoon” rapidly approached the Straits of Malacca, which gave access to the China seas.

events.text_segment:
The first few days of the voyage passed prosperously, amid favourable weather and propitious winds, and they soon came in sight of the great Andaman, the principal of the islands in the Bay of Bengal, with its picturesque Saddle Peak, two thousand four hundred feet high, looming above the waters. The steamer passed along near the shores, but the savage Papuans, who are in the lowest scale of humanity, but are not, as has been asserted, cannibals, did not make their appearance.
The panorama of the islands, as they steamed by them, was superb. Vast forests of palms, arecs, bamboo, teakwood, of the gigantic mimosa, and tree-like ferns covered the foreground, while behind, the graceful outlines of the mountains were traced against the sky; and along the coasts swarmed by thousands the precious swallows whose nests furnish a luxurious dish to the tables of the Celestial Empire. The varied landscape afforded by the Andaman Islands was soon passed, however, and the “Rangoon” rapidly approached the Straits of Malacca, which gave access to the China seas.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: The first few days of the voyage passed prosperously, amid favourable weather and propitious winds, and they soon came in sight of the great Andaman, the principal of the islands in the Bay of Bengal, with its picturesque Saddle Peak, two thousand four hundred feet high, looming above the waters. The steamer drew near the coast, skirting the lush shoreline where dense forests of palms, bamboo, teak, mimosa, and ferns stretched out in every direction, backed by rugged mountain ranges. The air was filled with the busy activity of swallows, whose nests, highly prized in China, could be seen along the cliffs and overhangs. Despite the proximity to the islands, the local Papuan inhabitants, described as non-cannibalistic savages, were not observed from the deck. As the vessel continued its course, it left the Andaman Islands behind and headed towards the Straits of Malacca, the vital gateway to the China Seas, marking the next stage of their journey.

events.text_segment: What was detective Fix, so unluckily drawn on from country to country, doing all this while? He had managed to embark on the “Rangoon” at Calcutta without being seen by Passepartout, after leaving orders that, if the warrant should arrive, it should be forwarded to him at Hong Kong; and he hoped to conceal his presence to the end of the voyage. It would have been difficult to explain why he was on board without awakening Passepartout’s suspicions, who thought him still at Bombay. But necessity impelled him, nevertheless, to renew his acquaintance with the worthy servant, as will be seen.
